FacilityName: Tampa LP Terminal - MPLX Terminals, LLC

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RELEASE POLICIES

Tampa LP Terminal - MPLX Terminals, LLC is a refined petroleum product distributor.  The Tampa LP Terminal is an on-shore, light products, bulk petroleum storage terminal used in the storage and distribution of petroleum products to retail and commercial end-users in the vicinity of Tampa, FL.  The Terminal handles and stores various grades of unleaded gasoline, low-sulfur diesel/#2 Fuel Oil, butane, ethanol, asphalt and various other petroleum based additives.

Tampa LP Terminal - MPLX Terminals, LLC (Marathon) in Tampa, FL is committed to operating and maintaining processes in a safe, reliable and environmentally sound manner.  Marathon believes that excellent performance in health, safety, and the environment goes hand in hand with operating reliably, and that outstanding HES performance is of paramount importance.

The Tampa LP Terminal is designed, operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of its employees, contractors and the community.  Marathon promotes health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection.  These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Marathon has designed and implemented, including:

A. A description of the facility and the use of regulated substances
B. An overview of the accidental release prevention programs
C. A five-year accident history for accidental releases of regulated chemicals
D. An overview of the emergency response program
E. An overview of planned changes to improve safety

A. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The primary function of the Tampa LP Terminal, located in Tampa, FL is to act as a refined petroleum distribution facility. The butane blending process has been classified as

Program Level 3. No Program 1 or 2 processes containing regulated substances were identified. By virtue of the flammable effects associated with butane, it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling butane to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to employee health, and to minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community. Tampa LP Terminal - MPLX Terminals, LLC is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety and health. Safety at the Facility depends upon the manner in which butane is handled as well as the various safety devices incorporated into the design of the process. Furthermore, comprehensive training is provided to employees, which reinforces the safety policies and procedures of the Tampa LP Terminal.

The facility has fixed inventories of butane. Butane is received by truck (transports) and stored in one (1) storage vessel. Specifically, liquefied butane is off-loaded by truck for storage under pressure. The butane is pumped to a blending skid for direct injection into regular/blend grade and premium unleaded gasoline lines feeding the site gasoline truck-loading rack. Injection quantities are controlled via an automated analyzer and process controls. Process safety controls include excess flow valves, fusible elements on pneumatic valves (fail safe in the closed position), fill shutoff on the vessel, manual and automatic emergency shutoff devices on the system, HMI system display at terminal office, pressure and hydrostatic reliefs, and grounding/interlock devices. Access to the Tampa LP Terminal is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel and authorized contractors/visitors as governed by the U.S. Coast Guard.

B. GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC
PREVENTION MEASURES

The Tampa LP Terminal accidental release prevention programs and emergency planning/response programs help Marathon effectively manage the hazards posed by t

e Tampa Fire Rescue and Hillsborough County Office of Emergency Management.  A Facility Response Plan (FRP) is in place to inform employees what to do in case of a release, fire, and to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response.

In the event of an emergency involving the Tampa LP Terminal butane blending system, it is the policy of the Facility to initially contact the Tampa Fire Rescue and request their assistance. The Facility maintains a trained (annually) incipient fire and 1st Responder Operations capability. The Tampa Fire Rescue has participated in butane training sessions for this system.

In addition to the training noted above, tours and drills with members of local emergency response organizations are offered routinely. These tours and drills enable the public emergency responders to become familiar with the hazards, equipment, resources and personnel in the Terminal.

E. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Marathon is continually striving to make the Tampa LP Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for its employees, neighbors and community.

In an effort to improve and promote system safety, Marathon actively seeks employee input on process safety improvements.  All Process Safety Events (as identified in API 754) are electronically recorded, reviewed, and/or investigated via a root cause analysis (TapRooT).  The Tampa Fire Rescue is contacted regarding participation in site emergency response drills. Additionally, Marathon will work cooperatively with the community to address any concerns.
